head.title: Song VI.11 First published in Poetical Essays (1788), pp. 222-223.

body.note: Tune. Woes my heart that we should sunder.22 The air is given in Robert Chambers, The Songs of Scotland Prior to Burns with the Tunes (Edinburgh: W. & R. Chambers, 1890), pp. 329-330. Chambers comments that Ramsay composed a new song “to supersede a homely one which had long possessed popular favour.” See Allan Ramsay, “With broken words and downcast eyes,” Tea Table Miscellany, 2 vols. (Edinburgh, 1724: Glasgow: Crum, 1871), I: pp. 79-80. Chambers also notes: “An air under the title of Alace my heart that we should sunder appears in Playford’s Collection, 1700. There is also one, essentially different from the above, in the Skene Manuscript, under the title of Alace this night that we suld sinder (p. 331).

lg.l: One night by Irvine’s murm’ring tide,33 The river Irvine flows through southwest Scotland, running near Kilmarnock, down to the coastal town of Irivine and is featured in many of Turnbull’s poems. Cf. “Elegy IV,” “Ode VII: To Irvine Water” and “Irvine Water” in Poetical Essays (1788).
As I a shady tree sat under,
And Colin,44 Shepherd-poet; Cf. Clement Marot, Complainte de Madame Loysc (1531); Edmund Spenser, Shepheardes Calendar (1579); and John Gay, The Shepherd’s Week (1714). seated by my side,
Gave me his hand we ne’er should sunder.
Believe, he cry’d, dear charming fair,
Thy beauty fires me all with wonder,
Long as I breathe the vital air,
We’ll live in love, and never sunder.
How could you, cruel youth, deceive,
How ruin one so young and tender;
Why did I, simple maid, believe,
And all my virgin-charms surrender:
Thy words such innocence display’d,
While false designs were lurking under,
Which me, unhappy nymph, betray’d,
And broke my tender heart asunder.
Ye murm’ring streams, ye shady groves,
Where first I heard the tale so tender;
Ye scenes of our once happy loves,
Where first my heart I did surrender;
Ye list’ning echoes, catch the strain,
Repeat, repeat the tale with wonder,
Upbraid the dear deluding swain,
Who broke my tender heart asunder.
